section.p: The administrator of the IdP system that is to be used for authenticating users requires the following information from the platform operator:

ul.li: The unique identifier of the tenant that issues authentication requests. This ID is generated when you create the tenant. The IdP system uses this ID for identifying incoming authentication requests.
The signature verification certificate of the platform. This is the same for all tenants.

p.b: Required configuration steps in the IdP system:

ol.li: The IdP operator must ensure that the correct endpoints for the Web UI SSO and STS connections are activated.
For each tentant, the IdP operator must create a relying party in the IdP system.

Each tenant must be registered with the IdP. For this, the generated tenant ID and the manually created ID as specified in the SSO_ISSUER_ID parameter must be provided to the IdP administrator, as well as the URL to which the IdP is to send its responses (as specified in the SSO_IDP_URL parameter). The IdP administrator also requires the logout URL (as specified in the SSO_LOGOUT_URL parameter).
The IdP administrator requires the signature verification certificate of the platform. The IdP system needs this certificate for handling logout requests.

The assertions returned to the platform must contain user IDs and the corresponding tenant ID for each user. This is required for the platform to map the users to the the platform user roles (such as administrator, service manager, marketplace manager), and to ensure the uniqueness of user IDs.
To achieve this, the IdP system must be configured such that its assertions contain two <AttributeStatement> elements. The first <Attribute> subelement must contain a Name="userid" property, and the <AttributeValue> subelement must specify the user ID that matches the ID of the calling user in the platform. The second <Attribute> subelement must contain a Name="tenantID" property, and the <AttributeValue> subelement must specify the ID of the tenant associated with the organization the corresponding user belongs to.
Example:
<saml:Assertion ...> ... <saml:AttributeStatement> <saml:Attribute Name="userid"> <saml:AttributeValue>administrator</saml:AttributeValue> </saml:Attribute> <saml:Attribute Name="tenantID"> <saml:AttributeValue>34ffd098</saml:AttributeValue> </saml:Attribute> </saml:AttributeStatement> </saml:Assertion>
Be aware that the SAML assertions returned from the IdP always need to contain the default tenant ID, even if you do not want to make use of the multi-tenancy functionality.
